docs.lead_paragraph: People with diabetes, overwhelmed by the cost of their prescriptions, often skip their medications to save money, two new studies report. As a result, the researchers said, the patients risk more severe problems, and may end up requiring even more expensive treatment.

headline.main: Dose Deletion: A Matter of Money

docs.abstract: Two studies, both led by Veterans Affairs Department researcher Dr John D Piette and published in Diabetes Care and Medical Care, find overwhelming number of individuals with diabetes skip their medications to save money; hold that those who skipped doses, many with limited health benefits, have more health problems then those who stick to regimen; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: People with diabetes, overwhelmed by the cost of their prescriptions, often skip their medications to save money, two new studies report.    As a result, the researchers said, the patients risk more severe problems, and may end up requiring even more...

docs.lead_paragraph: Radiation treatment is being prescribed for more and more breast cancer patients, including women who would have been told just a few years ago that they could skip it. The added therapy mostly affects those women who are treated with mastectomy and chemotherapy, and have fairly good prognoses at what is called Stage 2 cancer.

headline.main: A Debate on Radiation in Breast Cancer

docs.abstract: Breast cancer patients are at center of debate on effectiveness of radiation therapy on survival rates and recurrence rates of cancer; Dr Abram Recht, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center radiation oncology deputy chief, admits that individual Harvard hospitals follow differents protocols in determining post-operative radiation therapy; radiation for stage 2 breast cancer, which generally involves one to three positive auxiliary lymph nodes, has been shown in some studies to improve recurrence rates, but experts hold research has not been done in United States where surgical techniques are more aggressive; Dr Lori J Pierce, University of Michigan radiation oncology associate professor, stresses need for well-informed patient involvement in decision to undergo radiation therapy; photos, graph (L)
docs.snippet: Radiation treatment is being prescribed for more and more breast cancer patients, including women who would have been told just a few years ago that they could skip it.     The added therapy mostly affects those women who are treated with mastectomy...

docs.lead_paragraph: Hormone replacement for women past their childbearing years was originally popularized with the promise that taking estrogen could keep women ''feminine forever'' -- preserving their health, skin, bones, muscles, brains and, especially, their sexual pleasure. Now our youth-oriented culture has spawned another rush to fountain of youth drugs, this time testosterone for men. As with estrogen, testosterone -- the hormone that surges in puberty to turn boys into men -- is known to act on myriad tissues in the body, either directly or through its derivatives. Various studies have documented the influences of testosterone on bones, muscles, strength, stamina, abdominal fat, hair, mood, cognitive functions like memory and, of course, libido and potency.

headline.main: Age-Fighting Hormones Put Men at Risk, Too

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses reputed benefits and risks of male testosterone replacement therapies; holds no long term research has been completed, but use of drug, which in 1999 was taken by 648,000 men, has increased to 2 million prescriptions for testosterone in 2002; recent discovery that female hormone replacement therapy can lead to risk of heart problems has many doctors concerned about unknown factors in testosterone treatments; possible benefits discussed; importance of further testing stressed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Hormone replacement for women past their childbearing years was originally popularized with the promise that taking estrogen could keep women ''feminine forever'' -- preserving their health, skin, bones, muscles, brains and, especially, their sexual...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people with asthma who take pains to avoid substances or situations that may set off attacks may overlook a potential danger in their medicine cabinets, aspirin. Writing in the current issue of BMJ, a British medical journal, researchers say about one adult asthmatic in five can suffer a potentially life-threatening reaction to aspirin. For children with asthma, the rate is 1 in 20.
docs.abstract: Dr Christine Jenkins of Royal Albert Hospital (Camperdown, Australia) heads research published in BMJ, British Medical Journal, that shows potentially life-threatening link between aspirin and asthma; contends that one in five adult asthmatics are negatively Affected by aspirin and one in 20 children could suffer severe attack (S)
docs.snippet: Many people with asthma who take pains to avoid substances or situations that may set off attacks may overlook a potential danger in their medicine cabinets, aspirin.     Writing in the current issue of BMJ, a British medical journal, researchers say...

docs.lead_paragraph: The increase in the use of radiation after mastectomy has forced plastic surgeons to rethink their approach to reconstructive surgery of the breast and has generated a debate about which techniques yield the best (and worst) results. Radiation also limits the choices available to women seeking reconstruction and raises the risk of complications and poor cosmetic results. Some women are left with no good reconstruction options.

headline.main: Choices Now Harder in Erasing Cancer's Scars

docs.abstract: Increase in radiation treatment following mastectomy has created conflicting opinion over timing of and technique for breast reconstructive surgery; majority of surgeons, citing skin damage and potential complications, suggest waiting until radiation is complete before doing reconstruction; recent studies, however, show marginal increase in complications and more flexibility regarding type of reconstruction, if surgery is done before radiation; reconstruction options given; importance of patient preference discussed (M)
docs.snippet: The increase in the use of radiation after mastectomy has forced plastic surgeons to rethink their approach to reconstructive surgery of the breast and has generated a debate about which techniques yield the best (and worst) results.    Radiation...

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients who have had surgery to remove skin cancers report being more likely to use sun protection than they had been before the surgery, researchers say. The researchers, led by Dr. John S. Rhee of the Medical College of Wisconsin, interviewed more than 100 patients before skin cancer surgery and one and four months after. The patients had nonmelanoma skin cancer, which is generally not fatal. More than a million new cases are diagnosed in Americans each year, the study said.
docs.abstract: Dr John S Rhee, Wisconsin Medical College researcher, leads study published in Archives of Otolaryngology that showed impact of skin cancer removal caused majority of those surveyed to be more careful in protecting themselves from sun; 49 percent of patients used sunscreen prior to surgery and 72 percent in six-month period after procedure; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Patients who have had surgery to remove skin cancers report being more likely to use sun protection than they had been before the surgery, researchers say.    The researchers, led by Dr. John S. Rhee of the Medical College of Wisconsin, interviewed...

docs.lead_paragraph: Failing to brush and floss regularly may lead to more problems than cavities: a new study has found that poor oral health can be an indicator of heart disease. The researchers, writing in the journal Circulation, suggested that dentists consider referring patients with infection, tooth decay or other problems to a physician who can evaluate them for heart problems.
docs.abstract: Dr Sok-Ja Janket, Boston University dental school assistant professor reporting in journal Circulation, finds link between poor oral health and potential heart disease; suggests dentists refer patients to physicians for testing; infected wisdom teeth show highest correlation with heart risk; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Failing to brush and floss regularly may lead to more problems than cavities: a new study has found that poor oral health can be an indicator of heart disease.    The researchers, writing in the journal Circulation, suggested that dentists consider...

docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor I know maintains a fairly typical relationship with the pharmaceutical industry. He deplores its influence on medical practice and worries that his colleagues' prescribing habits are increasingly swayed by omnipresent drug advertisements and sales agents pumping new products.

headline.main: When Your Doctor Goes to the Beach, You May Get Burned

docs.abstract: Abigail Zuger essay explores impact of pharmaceutical company perks and samples on doctor's prescription choices; holds that while most doctors firmly believe they base decisions on unbiased medical knowledge, several studies show marketing by drug companies has impact; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: A doctor I know maintains a fairly typical relationship with the pharmaceutical industry.    He deplores its influence on medical practice and worries that his colleagues' prescribing habits are increasingly swayed by omnipresent drug advertisements...

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton gave new meaning to the phrase ''I feel your pain.'' But the results of a recent study may now give the words some scientific weight. Seeing a loved one endure a slight electrical shock, researchers have found, activates a brain region that processes pain, pointing to a possible neurological basis for empathy.

headline.main: Brain Senses The Pain Of Someone Else's 'Ouch!'

docs.abstract: Dr Tania Singer, University College London research fellow, leads study published in journal Science that supports idea that empathy has neurological base; MRI testing of 16 couples shows activity in emotional centers of brain when confronted with partner in physical pain; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Bill Clinton gave new meaning to the phrase ''I feel your pain.'' But the results of a recent study may now give the words some scientific weight.    Seeing a loved one endure a slight electrical shock, researchers have found, activates a brain...

docs.lead_paragraph: Vaccination against chickenpox has been routine in the United States for nearly a decade. But outbreaks of the illness among children who have already been immunized have raised new concerns about the effectiveness of the vaccine and the age when it is given.

headline.main: Chickenpox Vaccine Found to Fade in a Year

docs.abstract: American children have been routinely vaccinated for chickenpox over last ten years; new study, led by Dr Marietta Vazquez, Yale University researcher, finds effectiveness of vaccines fades substantially in year after it is administered and appears to be less efective on children under 15 months of age; holds effectiveness of vaccine does level off in second year; suggests change in vaccination age from 12 months old to 15 months, but other experts cite concerns some children will be missed if vaccinations are delayed; multiple doses discussed and evaluated; long-term effectiveness is undetermined (S)
docs.snippet: Vaccination against chickenpox has been routine in the United States for nearly a decade.    But outbreaks of the illness among children who have already been immunized have raised new concerns about the effectiveness of the vaccine and the age when...
